content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: Stabalize security in the country? Wow, sounds vaguely familiar. If more are sent in are they going to be scrutinized over ever little move they make? Or are they going to be able to do their job. Not easy to send 17,000 troops into harms way, is it? ----------------------------------------------- http://www.military.com/news/article/obama-early-to-mull-more-troops.html President Barack Obama says he needs to see how fast Afghanistan can be stabilized and led toward a more democratic government before deciding whether more troops are needed. In an interview with Newsweek magazine, Obama said the hardest thing he has had to do so far in his administration was to order 17,000 troops to Afghanistan on top of an estimated 38,000 that were already in Afghanistan. The interview was released on the Web Saturday. He did not rule out the possibility of sending even more troops, while stressing such a decision was premature at this point and that U.S. military action is not the only answer to bringing stability to the region. "We have to see our military action in the context of a broader effort to stabilize security in the country, allow national elections to take place in Afghanistan and then provide the space for the vital development work that's needed so that a tolerant and open, democratically elected government is considered far more legitimate than a Taliban alternative," Obama said. "My strong view is that we are not going to succeed simply by piling on more and more troops," he added. "The military component is critical to accomplishing that goal, but it is not a sufficient element by itself." Obama said he wrestled with his options before making the decision in February to order a surge of troops. He said he was sobered by the idea that many men and women could be harmed but that a surge was unavoidable. "The starting point was a recognition that the existing trajectory was not working, that the Taliban had made advances, that our presence in Afghanistan was declining in popularity, that the instability along the border region was destabilizing Pakistan as well," Obama said. We basically abandoned the place for six years. Not to mention that we made the worst possible choices in local Afghans to run the place. Bascially the US is in a far worse position then we were when we first invaded. At that time we had tremendous support amongst the locals, A discredited bunch of religious fanatics, etc, etc. So after six years of corrupt "tame" Fundamentalists, dope dealing war lords, and the inevitable mitakes of being dependant on air power (It was the only force we had left in Afghanistan) the Taliban have made a successful come back. Well, at least the Adults are in charge now, and I hope they can turn things around. Dave

content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: The point being... that the same information that Clinton has was the one that was being passed on the Bush and now on to Obama. Each president is only as good as the intel given at or preceding the time before him. No one knows the future and really, it's hard to tell what's going to happen in the next hour. This is was was known: Here is what was known by 1998 based on Iraq's own admissions: * That in the years immediately prior to the first Gulf War, Iraq produced at least 3.9 tons of VX, a deadly nerve gas, and acquired 805 tons of precursor ingredients for the production of more VX. * That Iraq had produced or imported some 4,000 tons of ingredients to produce other types of poison gas. * That Iraq had produced 8,500 liters of anthrax. * That Iraq had produced 500 bombs fitted with parachutes for the purpose of delivering poison gas or germ payloads. * That Iraq had produced 550 artillery shells filled with mustard gas. * That Iraq had produced or imported 107,500 casings for chemical weapons. * That Iraq had produced at least 157 aerial bombs filled with germ agents. * That Iraq had produced 25 missile warheads containing germ agents (anthrax, aflatoxin, and botulinum). ------------------ Obama now has the same and more information that we never see. He's in the position of knowing the past while considering the present and looking toward the future. Dave and Mixy, that one year... if not very careful can bring on more changes than we all might like to think about. Whatever I think of Mr. Clinton (and that's not much) he didn't get us into an open ended war in Iraq. Scott Ritter, the guy in charge of the inspectors stated catagorically that they destroyed 95 percent of Iraqs weapons, and all of their means for making new ones. He also pointed out that those weapons left, if any, had expired. But this is all besides the point. Even if I granted that Iraq was a threat in the future, the question was how to deal with the threat that actually attacked us, and THAT was Afghanistan. I find it bizzare and beyond belief that we left Afghanistan with the job only barely begun, to go off and, well, basically attack someone ELSE because he didn't like us and said bad things about Georges's mother... Dave
